root: ^The air was stuffy. The smell of wet clothes emanated from the cells.
^Those prisoners who were fast or lucky, took the bunks. The less fortunate men occupied few spots on the floor between and under the beds.
^Every single person was exhausted, the journey to the North was long.
^The prisoners were told to wait until morning. At the break of dawn, three old trucks would take them further North, to the Kolyma labor camps.
^Arkady was shivering on his bottom bunk. He was about to turn on the side and try to fall asleep when suddenly he felt that someone was looking at him.
^A man approached his bed. The stranger had a strong presence. He was exhausted like everyone else, and yet Arkady could tell that his spirit was not broken.
^There are rules, there are circumstances. Things one has to deal with, has to respect.
^But there’s also luck. You can’t rely on it, but nevertheless it exists.
^People often forget about luck, they don’t believe in it. However, sometimes Lady Fortuna appears out of nowhere and brings salvation.
^Here’s an example. Hm, let's give it a try...
^I know the rules. You were here first and the bed is yours. You know, I never ask for anything, but can I sit here? It's been a long and tiring journey.
^You may sit down. But do not forget you're sleeping on the floor tonigh.
^Of course. Sit down here, it's hard to stand in such a crowded cell.

c-0: ^Oh, I am so grateful. See? There’s always a chance of something good to happen even at such a miserable place like this jail.
c-1: ^Of course. See? There’s always a chance of something good to happen even at such a miserable place.
^But rules are rules, there are limits. The floor is not the worst option, although I really doubt anyone will be able to catch any proper sleep in this cold cell.
c-2: ^Ah! Your heart is soft. Don't worry, it won't stay that way for too long.
g-0: ^Arkady knew that name. The name of a legendary revolutionary, who, as they say, took part in several assassinations of high rank Imperial officials thirty years ago.
^Here we are. 45 days on a train, 2 days on a boat.
^I've been to this part of Russia before, but never could I imagine I'd have to travel all the way to Magadan again.
^I know you. You were a member of the Socialist Revolutionary Party.
^Former terrorist? I thought you left the country.
^I heard you were a spy. Was it another false accusation?

c-1: ^I did. But Soviet agents lured me into a trap. I have no regrets though. The chances were extremely slim, but I had to roll the dice again, to push my luck. Otherwise I would never forgive myself.
^To be honest, I'd rather die here than in France, among all those impotent boring Russian immigrants.
c-2: ^It sure was. They needed those spy cases for the Purge to happen.
g-0: ^It is quite ironic. The Imperial Okhrana came after me in 1907. The officer who interrogated me said I was a threat to the Tsarist government.
^And today, 30 years later, I am an enemy of the Soviet state. Things haven’t changed for me that much.
^All those sentimental idiots say that The Revolution was a dream that never came true.
^The Revolution was first and foremost an opportunity. We had our chance and we lost it. What is your name?

c-0: ^If you don't mind me asking, was General Kojukh your father?
^Yes. General Valentin Kojukh was my father.
^His trial was a joke, and you could tell how badly those miserable party clerks wanted to get rid of him.

c-1: ^As you wish. I have heard someone here call you Arkady. That's good enough for me.
g-0: ^Arkady turned his face to the wall. He wanted to hide his emotions. The stranger touched a wound that was still fresh.
^Andreyev felt that too. For a minute the old revolutionary became silent, he was preoccupied with his thoughts. Then he gave Arkady a long look and said:
^Let me give you some advice. Forget about your former self. You are a prisoner now. Focus on more important matters.
^Your body and your mind are about to go through one of the most terrible trials. You will experience life without freedom.
^Don’t think too much about the past or about the future, these thoughts will make you weak. All you have is present, here and now.
^Distract your mind from counting seconds of the time you have to do in the North. Actually, I have an idea.
^Let's play a simple game. It's called $Numbers. The game is old and every prisoner is familiar with it, so you better remember the rules. It might even save your life one day so listen carefully.
